funFacts: The Middle English period has no standardized spelling; Chaucer himself spelled ‘through’ at least ten different ways.
The letter ‘ȝ’ (yogh) in Middle English could represent /j/, /g/ or /x/, and is the ancestor of the modern ‘y’ in Scottish surnames like ‘Menzies’ (pronounced /ˈmɪŋɪs/).
Only about 55–60 % of core Middle English vocabulary survived into Modern English untouched; the rest was replaced or heavily changed.
Middle English absorbed roughly 10,000 Norman French words after 1066, many of which relate to law, cuisine and fashion.
Printing-press pioneer William Caxton (1476) helped transition from Middle to Early Modern English by arbitrarily choosing spellings that looked ‘prestigious’.
‘Girl’ originally meant ‘child of either sex’ in Middle English; the female-only sense appeared later.
